Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at.

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service policies
Description and procedures that address all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
2

(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth's medication is getting mixed up and coming up missing. The
specific medication that is missing is a controlled substance. There are
concerns with medication abuse at the facility.
Investigation A complaint was received on 1/5/23 stating Youth A's medication is
getting mixed up and coming up missing. Youth A's mother said she
does not open the packages from the pharmacy. She takes the
medication from the pharmacy directly to the facility. Just the Adderall
was getting mixed up not the other 3 medications. Youth A's mother
reported she heard the facility was having problems with staff leaving
the job due to medication abuse.
Interviews:
A phone call was made to the complainant on 1/5/23. He reported he
talked to Youth A's Juvenile Court Officer (JCO) about Youth A's
medication going missing. The facility and JCO have indicated the
issue is with mom not providing the facility with all of her son’s
medication but the mom said it is the youth center that is taking Youth
A's Adderall.
A phone call was placed to the Chief Administrator (CA) on 1/5/23. She
is aware of the issue. Youth A's mother told the judge about the missing
medication and she has been doing an investigation.
I met with the CA face to face at the facility on 1/9/23 and the CA was
read the allegations. She reported none of her staff have left due to
medication abuse. She reported in mid-December she received an e-
mail from a judge indicating she needed to conduct an investigation to
find out where Youth A's medication went. Reportedly, the Mom told the
court that 10 days of Youth A's Adderall was missing. That was 30 pills
as he gets them 3 times a day so the CA started her investigation. The
CA said that during the time he did not have his Adderall mom did bring
in his other medication. She reviewed Youth A's medication logs and
pill counts and found there were missed doses. The staff missed
passing noon and 4pm medication because they are not used to
passing medication outside of morning and bedtime. She stated the
shift supervisor is supposed to count medication in. She was not sure
why Staff 1 counted in pills. Their video system only goes back 15 days
so they would not have video recordings of when the medication came
in. Currently anyone who walks into the control room can access the
medication.
4

A phone call was placed to Youth A's Juvenile Court Officer (JCO) and
he stated he contacted the pharmacy about Youth A not having
medication in August/September and they reported the medication was
picked up but they could not say who picked it up. The JCO said that on
12/31/22 mom took a pill bottle to the youth center that was not a full
prescription. He called the pharmacy who indicated to him that they
would never give a partial fill of Adderall.
A visit to Youth A's pharmacy occurred on 1/9/23. The Pharmacist
indicated only the parent could get a printout of Youth A's medication
unless a court order could be provided. The Pharmacist said they can
fill partial prescriptions but then they would need a new prescription for
controlled substances.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 1/9/23. He stated
his mom has a complaint about the facility. He stated 10 days worth of
pills were missing. He takes Adderall 3 times a day, so it was 30 pills.
He thought Supervisor 1 was taking them because his mom told him
that is who she gave them to. Youth A said Supervisor 1 called the
cops on his mom. He stated Supervisor 1 told the cops his mom took
his medication. He stated his mom would never do that as she knows
he needs his medication and she is always on top of it. He said not
taking his medication can hurt him. He reported sometimes he does not
get his noon dose but gets it 1-2 hours later. The same thing happens
with his 4pm dose.
Mom was interviewed via telephone on 1/10/23. She reported a month
ago she talked in court about her son not getting his medication and
that his medication had gone missing. The Judge ordered an
investigation. There were 2 occasions when she took Youth A's
medication to the facility. The first time the staff said they were off by 1
pill. Then she finds out he has 30 pills missing. She said the facility will
contact the JCO when they need refills. JCO is supposed to pick up the
medication from the pharmacy but the JCO was not doing it, so she did
it. Mom clarified that it was in November that Youth A was missing 30
pills and it was Supervisor 1 that told her the pills were missing. On
12/21/22, Youth A should have been out of his Adderall but he had 19
pills left. Mom said Youth A needs his medication or he will have trouble
controlling his behavior. During the medication drop offs, the staff did
not count the medication with her. She would bring the pharmacy bag
that was stapled closed to the facility. She would never open the bag.
She said she never took partial prescriptions to them. If she did the
pharmacy would change the number and initial it. She said she never
took her sons medication. She was asked to obtain a printout from the
pharmacy to show what medications were filled for Youth A. She said
she would get it and provide it.
4

A phone call was made to Youth A's mom on 1/20/23. She stated she
forgot about the pharmacy printout of Youth A's medication. She asked
that I text her tomorrow at noon to remind her to pick it up.
A text message was sent to Youth A's mother on 1/21/23 reminding her
to get the pharmacy print out. No response was received.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed by telephone on 1/12/23. She stated she
logged Youth A's medication in a few different times. A few times mom
brought all but Youth A's Adderall. One time Supervisor 1 said when
she counted in Youth A's medication the Clonidine was short. The
bottle said 30 pills were in it but she only counted 28. Supervisor 1 also
had another staff count and the count was still 28. She then let mom
know. Supervisor 1 said it is preferable that the supervisor count
medication in but if they are not available then the staff in control can
count them. When medication comes in it is dropped off at the back
door then staff take it and put it in the control room for it to be counted.
They can contact either the parent or the JCO to get medication refills.
In August, Supervisor 1 said she told mom Youth A was out of his
Adderall. The JCO e-mailed the supervisors and stated mom told him
no one informed her Youth A was out of his Adderall. Supervisor 1
stated she e-mail the JCO back stating she did in fact tell mom.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed via telephone on 1/11/23. He reported a
few weeks ago he noted Youth A's mother dropped off his medication
and she said there were only 28 Adderall pills. This was a red flag for
him as he had never heard of a pharmacy giving a partial prescription.
Nor had he seen that the number on the bottle was crossed off and a
new number with an initial would be in its place. He was aware Youth A
went 3-4 months without his Adderall previously. Per Supervisor 3,
there are three different ways medication can come into the facility. The
parent, the JCO, or facility staff pick it up and bring it in. If they have a
refill on the bottle they will order the refill themselves then go pick it up
at the pharmacy. When Youth A's medication was dropped off,
Supervisor 3 had a staff go get it from the mom as he watched on the
monitor. The staff brought him the medication and he counted it right
away. The medication bottle was in a bag from the pharmacy not
stapled. Supervisor 3 stated it was mom's initials on the bottle.
Supervisor 3 clarified that the only time someone other than a
supervisor counts the medication is when the supervisor is not available
then the person in control does it. This is the same for passing
medication. Supervisors pass all medication unless they are
unavailable then it is the person in control. This was in place because
they did not want too many hands on the medication, especially
Adderall. Per Supervisor 3, they are good at remembering to give the
4

youth their medication and they have a medication reminder written on
the control room board.
Staff 1 was interviewed by telephone on 1/17/23. She reported she has
not been at the facility for some time. She could not remember ever
counting Youth A's medication. She reported a supervisor would
sometimes have her count medications when they are brought into the
facility if he was busy, but she did not remember if this ever occurred
with Youth A's medication. She did know that Youth A went without
medication, and she had heard it was due to mom not bringing it in.
She reported Youth A always got his medication if it was available. Staff
1 reported that all staff are aware there are cameras everywhere and
they record everything. There is even a camera facing the medication
cart in the control room.
Messages were left for Supervisor 2 and Supervisor 4.
Facility Tour:
A tour of the facility was conducted on 1/9/2023. There is a control
room in the center of the facility with windows facing the two day-
rooms. The control room was locked from the outside and only control
or people with keys can open the door. Inside the control room is a
medication cart. At the time of the tour the cart was open. A Ziplock bag
of medication sat on the desk next to the cabinet. Inside the cabinet
was a box with a lock on it that was not locked. In the box were Ziplock
bags with youth names on them. There were four of us inside the
control room at the time and other staff came and went. The staff was
told to lock up the medication.
Documentation review:
• Medication Logs: All logs from June of 2022 (when Youth A was
admitted) to January 9. The logs were missing a significant
number of initials indicating staff passed Youth A's medication.
Most of the missing initials were from the noon and 4pm doses.
Youth A was out of his Adderall on 8/2/22. He did not get it again
until 10/21/22. He was out of Adderall again on 11/16 through
11/21.
• Medication Count Logs: These logs indicated that Youth A was
admitted with a 30-day supply of Adderall. Between the end of
that first bottle and when the second bottle came in on 10/21/22
Youth A had all of his other medication brought in by mom or the
pharmacy. On 10/21/22, 89 pills of Adderall were counted in but
the bottle said 90. This discrepancy is not addressed on the
form.
• Comparing the Count Logs with the Medication logs Youth A
was out of Adderall on 11/16 after getting a new prescription less
4

than a month before. The following prescription came in on
11/21 with 90 pills, but 102 pills were passed before he ran out
again. Given the number of missing initials on the medication
logs and the number of pills that came in, all pills seem to be
accounted for.
• Internal Investigation Report: The following information was
pulled from CA’s report. On 12/15/22 the judge asked CA to
conduct an investigation. A docket entry indicated mom brought
this concern up to JCO on 11/21/22. Supervisor 1 contacted
mom in August letting her know Youth A would be out of his
Adderall. She also e-mailed JCO. In November Youth A ran out
of Adderall and Supervisor 1 let mom know. Mom told
Supervisor 1 Youth A should not have been out of his Adderall.
During CA's interview of the supervisors, they reported they were
unaware of any staff having issues with medication.
Communication between JCO and the pharmacy found Youth
A's medications were picked up in September and October, but
they could not say who picked them up. The pharmacy also told
JCO the only people who could pick up Youth A's medication
were Youth A's mom and grandmother.
• Medical & Health Care Services policy: Medications shall be
administered according to the physician's orders. The
administration of medication will be recorded on an approved
form and signed or initialed by the staff member administering
the medication. Controlled substances will be stored in locked
containers. Controlled substances on hand shall be inventoried
once a month and any losses should be reported immediately.
• Youth A’s medication bottles were the same as indicated on the
count logs and in interviews.
Analysis When counting all the pills received by the facility and all the pills given
from the count logs and the medication logs, it appears all pills are
accounted for, however, the agency is in violation of the rule as the
medication logs indicate Youth A was out of medication in November
when he should not have been and there was an abundance of pills left
over the following month. This indicates there are deficiencies in how
the facility brings medication in, counts the medication, dispenses the
medication, and documents all of these steps. Medication logs were
observed to have a large number of missing initials resulting in an
inability to determine if Youth A received his medication. During the on-
site medication was seen out on a desk and the medication cart was
open. These practices are not in line with the facility's Medical & Health
Care Services policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current authorization status be continued.
